Abandon all familiar patron families and relatives, and should follow the wisdom of one's own practice, and should not be the same as lay householders.
Always follow and obey the precepts.
KÄÅ›yapa!
If there are people in the world who have thoughts of going against the prÄtimoká¹£a, then they will be going against the Buddha's powers and fearlessness.

If they give rise to opposition towards the Buddha's powers and fearlessness, then they give rise to opposition towards the Buddhas of the past, present, and future. As a result, they will experience immeasurable great suffering in their future rebirths.

Even if all the sentient beings in the trichiliocosm were to experience the suffering of the hells, it would not compare to even a hundredth, a thousandth, a hundred thousandth, or even a koá¹­i-niyuta-Å›atasahasra-kalpa-s of the suffering experienced by those sentient beings.
If one wishes to be far removed from such suffering and distress, one should be far removed from such kinds of evil conduct.

If one should abandon them even if one only hears their names, how much more so if one sees and hears them and does not distance oneself from them?
Therefore, one should be intimate with one dharma.
What is that one dharma?
It is that all dharmas are ultimately non-existent.
If one attains the acceptance of the non-existence of all dharmas, then one will not associate with or make offerings to such evil people.
This person should also be close to two dharmas.
What are the two?
It means seeking the original non-existence of all dharmas and seeking the nature of all dharmas, but one should not give rise to a seeking mind.
How should one seek?

As what is sought is completely unobtainable, in the unobtainable one should not give rise to a mind of non-attainment, like a wrong view. In this way, one should be free from a mind of the three realms and accord with the practice of bodhi;
One should be free from a mind of all characteristics and accord with the practice of bodhisattvas.
The practice of bodhisattvas refers to what was said before as the practice of bodhisattvas.

Therefore, having heard this Dharma, one should abandon it, and then in the future one will personally be able to serve and attend to Maitreya, the World-Honored One, without arrogance or inferiority, and proclaim:
How wonderful and blissful!

If in the future they hear this sÅ«tra, are not startled or frightened, and see themselves following it, and are able to give rise to the resolve to uphold this teaching, the Buddha knows that these people will certainly protect my true Dharma.

It is like an elder whose wealth and treasures are immeasurable. His son sees a water vessel in the house, and thinks of it as his father's property.
At another time, when his father has passed away and the family wealth is scattered and lost, he suddenly sees that vessel and thinks to himself:

At that time, the bhiká¹£us will also be like this. Having heard this sÅ«tra, they will think:

I also know and see such people, and I entrust them all to Maitreya Buddha, who in the final period will be their protector, guarding the Dharma city of the Tathagata, and will then be the one who gives greatly without obstruction.
Furthermore, Kasyapa!
If good men hear this Dharma and practice it according to their wisdom, accomplishing beings with deep faith and right views, they will encounter Maitreya Buddha in the future.

I now look everywhere, and do not see a single person who will not be close to me, who in the future will not slander this sutra for fifty years, and who will be able to uphold and recite it. There is no such person.

You should study this Dharma.

' If they answer:

This Dharma is the Dharma of good men, namely the notion of non-practice regarding all practices, because it is difficult to understand.

If there is a view of self, a view of sentient beings, a view of life, a view of an individual, a view of existence, or if one gives rise to a view of precepts based on the aggregates, or if one gives rise to a view of much learning, a view of the Buddha, a view of the Dharma, or a view of nirvana, the Tathagata knows all of these to be wrong views.
Why is it so?
The Buddha has no discrimination or attainment with regard to nirvana.
If one gives rise to discrimination and attainment with regard to nirvana, the Tathagata completely declares them to be wrong views.

If one has wrong views, it is called ignorance. If one is ignorant, it is called harm. If one is harmful, it is called a foolish person. Being called a foolish person means having no desire for great enlightenment, up to being far removed from the supreme path leading to rebirth in the heavens.

At the time of their death, their sinful intentions will obstruct them. Having carefully considered their transgressions and indolently failed to practice, they will demonstrate attainment in three places.
What are the three?
Either they will falsely display dignified deportment, or they will falsely appear to be practicing pure conduct, or they will raise their hands and proclaim, I am unequaled.

Demonstrating attainment through these three places, these people will all fall into the state of overweening pride. At the time of their death, their minds will give rise to regret. After their lives end, they will be reborn in the hells.

Terrifying the army of evil mÄras, just like a pack of jackals.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Then the Greatly Compassionate World-Honored One, out of pity for the multitude of beings,
For the five bhiká¹£us he spoke, and the fruit of nectar was accomplished in time.

Either during cultivation, life ended, or setting out, life ended,

From that time onward, the vast Dharma sank,
Those who upheld the precepts and violated them, all would obtain offerings.

You observe the bhiká¹£us, there are such distinctions.

These lamps that illuminate the world, those who have compassion for the world,

Making offerings to that TathÄgata, in the assembly receiving his prediction,
In accordance with their thoughts and memories, for them with great spiritual power.
I speak words of sincerity and truth, comforting such people,

Quickly attaining a male body, and seeing Maitreya,
